%text Generally speaking, dealing with $\tan\phi$ or $\tan^{-1} x$ is easier than dealing with $\cot\phi$ or $\cot^{-1}x$. So, let us try to go from $\cot^{-1} x\longrightarrow\tan^{-1}x$ first.
Now, we know that \[ \cot^{-1} x = \tan^{-1}\dfrac{1}{x} \neq \dfrac{1}{\tan^{-1} x}\]
Therefore \[ \cot^{-1}\left( 1-x+x^2\right) = \tan^{-1}\left( \dfrac{1}{1-x+x^2}\right) \] %

%text We have already established that
% \begin{align} \cot^{-1}(1-x+x^2) &= \tan^{-1}\dfrac{1}{1-x+x^2} \\ &= \tan^{-1} x + \tan^{-1}(1-x) \\ \therefore \int_0^1 \cot^{-1}(1-x+x^2) &= \int_0^1\tan^{-1} x \cdot dx \\ &+ \int_0^1 \tan^{-1}(1-x)\cdot dx \end{align} %text
Recall that \[ \int_0^a f(x)\cdot dx = \int_0^a f(a-x)\cdot dx \]
And therefore, % \begin{align} A &= \int_0^1\tan^{-1}x\cdot dx + \int_0^1\tan^{-1}(1-x)\cdot dx \\ &= \underbrace{\int_0^1\tan^{-1}x\cdot dx}_{\text{No change}} + \underbrace{\int_0^1\tan^{-1} [1-(1-x)]\cdot dx} _{f(x) = 1-x \implies f(1-x) = 1-(1-x) = x}\\ &= \int_0^1 \tan^{-1}x\cdot dx + \int_0^1 \tan^{-1}x\cdot dx \\ &= 2 \int_0^1 \tan^{-1}x\cdot dx \end{align}
